Introduction

Dermatitis herpetiformis is a cutaneous manifestation of gluten sensitivity that is characterized by clusters of erythematous papules, vesicles, and bullae on the extensor surfaces (eg, elbows, knees), buttocks, and back.  Herpetiformis refers to the resemblance of the clustered vesicles to those of herpes simplex.  Most patients (ie, ~90%) have underlying gluten-sensitive enteropathy (ie, celiac disease), even if asymptomatic.

Pathogenesis and risk factors



The pathogenesis of dermatitis herpetiformis involves gluten exposure in a genetically susceptible patient.



Following the absorption of gluten, gliadin peptides elicit a T-cellâ€“mediated inflammatory cascade (

figure 1
).  Gliadin is absorbed into the intestinal mucosa and deaminated by tissue transglutaminase in a process involving formation of covalent crosslinks between them.  Because of this, the subsequent immune response against gliadin also targets tissue transglutaminase.  The deaminated gliadin then binds to the surface of antigen-presenting cells (primarily HLA DQ2 and HLA DQ8).



CD4+ T-helper cells recognize the bound gliadin, and on activation, produce proinflammatory cytokines that damage tissue within the intestinal mucosa.  In addition, the T-helper cells induce production of transglutaminase autoantibodies by B cells.  The circulating anti-epidermal transglutaminase autoantibodies bind epidermal transglutaminase and immune complex deposition in the dermis resulting in complement activation and neutrophil recruitment that leads to the characteristic bullous rash.



Therefore, risk factors for dermatitis herpetiformis include:



  • Expression of HLA DQ2 or DQ8 alleles
  • Family history of celiac disease or dermatitis herpetiformis

Clinical presentation



The clinical presentation of dermatitis herpetiformis involves intensely pruritic clusters of erythematous papules, vesicles, and bullae that are symmetrically distributed on the extensor surfaces (eg, elbows (

image 1
), knees, buttocks (
image 2
)).  Although less common, the face and neck may also be involved.  Excoriations and erosions from unroofed vesicles are common.  Scarring is rare, but postinflammatory hypo- or hyperpigmentation may occur.  The rash is chronic with episodic exacerbations.



Although most patients have underlying celiac disease, many are asymptomatic.  If symptoms are present, they are often nonspecific and mild (eg, bloating, diarrhea).  Rarely, severe symptoms can lead to iron deficiency anemia and weight loss.

Diagnosis



In cases of suspected dermatitis herpetiformis, diagnostic testing involves:



  • Biopsy:  A punch biopsy is obtained from a site that includes an intact vesicle.  Dermatitis herpetiformis is characterized histologically by microabscesses at the tips of the dermal papillae that contain neutrophils, eosinophils, and fibrin.  The microabscesses can coalesce to form subepidermal blisters (
    image 3
    ).  Direct immunofluorescence microscopy reveals granular IgA deposits along the dermoepidermal junction (
    image 4
    ).
  • Serology:  Typically shows elevated anti-tissue transglutaminase and anti-epidermal transglutaminase antibodies.  Total serum IgA should be measured to exclude IgA deficiency, which can cause false-negative serologic results.

Differential diagnosis



The differential diagnosis of dermatitis herpetiformis includes other bullous and nonbullous skin diseases, including (

table 1
):



  • Bullous pemphigoid (
    image 5
    ):  Characterized by tense bullae with an erythematous base on the flexural, not extensor, surfaces.  Direct immunofluorescence microscopy reveals linear IgG and/or C3 deposits along the basement membrane.
  • Pemphigus vulgaris:  Characterized by flaccid bullae with associated oral lesions (not seen with dermatitis herpetiformis).  In addition, there is often sloughing of the skin.
  • Linear IgA bullous dermatosis:  An IgA-mediated subepidermal blistering disorder, similar to dermatitis herpetiformis.  However, direct immunofluorescence microscopy reveals linear, rather than granular, IgA deposits along the dermoepidermal junction.
  • Atopic dermatitis (
    figure 2
    ):  Characterized by an intensely pruritic rash along the flexural surfaces.  Vesicles are not common.

Management



The management of dermatitis herpetiformis involves the adherence to a strict gluten-free diet; many patients see symptom improvement within weeks of initial dietary modification.



Dapsone, an immunomodulator, provides rapid relief within 24-28 hours of initiation of therapy and is often used for symptom relief while the patient transitions to a gluten-free diet.  This is because dapsone has multiple potential adverse effects, including hemolysis (particularly in patients with G6PD deficiency), methemoglobinemia (eg, cyanosis, headache, fatigue), and agranulocytosis.  Serial laboratory testing (eg, complete blood count, liver function tests) is required during dapsone therapy to monitor for these adverse effects.

Prognosis



The prognosis of dermatitis herpetiformis is favorable with lifelong adherence to a strict gluten-free diet.  Symptoms may recur with discontinuation of a gluten-free diet.



In addition to celiac disease, dermatitis herpetiformis is associated with other autoimmune conditions, including type I diabetes mellitus and autoimmune thyroiditis.

Summary



Dermatitis herpetiformis is a cutaneous manifestation of gluten sensitivity that is characterized by clusters of erythematous papules, vesicles, and bullae on the extensor surfaces (eg, elbows, knees), buttocks, and back.  Diagnosis involves biopsy with direct immunofluorescence microscopy revealing granular IgA deposits along the dermoepidermal junction.  Most patients have underlying gluten-sensitive enteropathy (ie, celiac disease), and management involves lifelong adherence to a strict gluten-free diet.
